Comment: **From reporter Jillian Wilson:**  Most people grow out of name-calling by about the ninth grade ‚Äî maybe 12th grade if you‚Äôre particularly immature. By that time, you‚Äôre likely aware that calling someone names is mean, aggressive and not actually a good way to create a positive change in a relationship.  This can‚Äôt be said, though, for Donald Trump, who purposely name-calls (like when he labels his critics and opponents ‚Äúhaters,‚Äù ‚Äúfake,‚Äù ‚Äúbad people‚Äù or ‚Äúcrazy‚Äù).  Experts say this is a pointed strategy. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs demagoguery is what he‚Äôs doing,‚Äù said¬†[Patricia Roberts-Miller](https://www.patriciarobertsmiller.com/), a professor emerita of rhetoric and writing who taught at the University of Texas at Austin.  There‚Äôs lots that goes into demagoguery, but to put it simply,¬†[it‚Äôs political rhetoric that uses emotions and prejudices](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/demagogue)¬†to push forward an agenda.  It‚Äôs proven to be an effective strategy for Trump, but is a clear red flag in what it reveals about the way he leads and views others.   Here's a link to the full article: [https://www.huffpost.com/entry/trump-demagoguery-political-strategy\_l\_68069b30e4b052543c13a003?utm\_medium=Social&utm\_source=reddit&utm\_campaign=us\_main](https://www.huffpost.com/entry/trump-demagoguery-political-strategy_l_68069b30e4b052543c13a003?utm_medium=Social&utm_source=reddit&utm_campaign=us_main)
